newsitem.title: USA: OMB's Raines predicts U.S. budget deal will pass.
newsitem.headline: OMB's Raines predicts U.S. budget deal will pass.

text.p: Franklin Raines, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said Tuesday the budget deal reached Monday between the White House and Congress would "absolutely" get congressional approval.

Asked on ABC's "Good Morning America" if he thought the agreement would have the congressional support it needs to pass, Raines said, "Absolutely. I believe it will have ... far more votes than necessary to pass it."

After months of difficult negotiations, President Clinton and Republican leaders reached an accord to balance the federal budget for the first time in a generation and cut taxes by $90 billion over the next five years.
The agreement will boost spending on education by $40 billion and start a $24 billion health insurance program for uninsured children.
The plan will raise the $0.24-per-pack cigarette tax by $0.15 and extend the airline ticket tax to raise about $30 billion through 2002.
